comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
The London Gazette has this:

York & Lanc Reg
Capt. H. K. E. Ostle, M.C. (Lond. R., T.F.), relinquishes the actg. rank of Lt.-Col. on ceasing to comd. a Bn. 15 Feb. 1918.

So, looking in ancestry.co.uk, it would seem that Henry Knight Eaton-Ostle married Ethel Anne Walter in 1928 (Kensington RD) and died on 10 September 1958, aged 76 at St Bartholomews Hospital, London and left his estate to his widow. 

In 1911, he was an insurance official, aged 29 and born in London.

He also appears on the UK Incoming Passengers Lists and the New York Passenger Lists.

comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content: In 1901, he was living at St Bartholomew's Hospital with his father - William Ostle, aged 55, born Maryport, Cumberland, clergyman for the Church of England (described as a hospitaller), his mother - Jane Lewis Ostle, aged 52, born Swansea and siblings - Helen Muriel Ostle, aged 19, born London and Douglas Wellesley Ostle, aged 7, born London

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Henry Knight Eaton Ostle as Lieutenant (Temporary Captain) 28th Battalion The London Regiment (Territorial Force) wef 11th January 1916 [London Gazette 14th January 1916].

In the London Gazette of 7th November 1916, Lt (Temp Capt) H K E Ostle to be Temp Major of The Artists' Rifles OTC with precedence from 1st June 1916 [published on 4th July 1916].

By 17th August 1917 he had been awarded his Military Cross (Gazette citation not found) and was a Lt (Temp Major) with seniority as a Capt (Temp Major) from 1st June 1916.

In the London Gazette of 15th January 1915, Captain H K E Ostle MC (London Regiment, TF) is shown to be Acting Major and Second in Command of a battalion of the York & Lancs Regt wef 26th October 1917.  In the London Gazette of 24th May 1918, Captain H K E Ostle (London Regt) is reported transferred from a Service Battalion of the York & Lancs Regt to the Somerset Light Infantry as a Temporary Major.//

comment.author: 77788549@N05
comment._content:
Lt. (temp. Capt.) Henry Knight Eaton Ostle — M.C.  ARTISTS (28TH LONDON)

Military Cross Citation

For conspicuously good and devoted work since the com- 
mencement of the campaign as an Instructor of Cadet Officers 
and Non-Commissioned Officers. He has invariably displayed 
great ability and energy in the performance of his duties, and 
has always been ready to undertake any work, however 
difficult or hazardous.

comment.author: 15161049@N06
comment._content: Much later the Artists Rifles became 21 Squadron Special Air Service I think - certainly Mars and Minerva was their squadron emblem.  I always wanted to see this badge on a unform.
